SEARCH
Module com.example.loginpage
Package com.example.loginpage.controller.dao

Class UserDAO

java.lang.Object
com.example.loginpage.controller.dao.UserDAO
All Implemented Interfaces:
DAO
public class UserDAO extends Object implements DAO
The UserDAO class is responsible for managing the interaction of user data with the database. This class handles creating, reading, updating, and deleting user information. Includes methods for performing asynchronous database operations, which allows me to avoid blocking calls

    • executeInBackground

      public void executeInBackground(Runnable task)
      Executes a task in the background using a thread from the executor.
      Parameters:
      task - The task to execute.

    • index

      public List<User> index()
      Retrieves all users from the database. This method executes the database query asynchronously and waits for the operation to complete using a CountDownLatch.
      Specified by:
      index in interface DAO
      Returns:
      A list of User objects representing all users in the database.

    • save

      public boolean save(Object entity)
      Attempts to save the specified object in the database. This method is designed to handle saving User objects to the database
      Specified by:
      save in interface DAO
      Parameters:
      entity - The object to be saved. Ideally, this should be an instance of User.
      Returns:
      false to indicate that the method is not yet implemented.

    • delete

      public boolean delete(int userId, int currentUser)
      Deletes a user from the database based on the provided user ID.
      Specified by:
      delete in interface DAO
      Parameters:
      userId - The ID of the user to delete.
      currentUser - The ID of the current user.
      Returns:
      True if the user was deleted successfully, false otherwise.

      public User show(String email, String password)

      Parameters:

      password - The password of the user.
      Returns:
      The User object if found, null otherwise.
